headline: Grade 12 IB Student at WVSS, BC Chess Champion, VEX Robotics Worlds Competitor, Shad Ambassador - "Improve 1% a day, 37.8 times better a year"
summary:
Hey there!
My name is Eric, formal name Tao Xie, and I am a Grade 12 IB Diploma student here at West Vancouver Secondary School in BC, Canada.
I am passionate about pursuing a career in the STEM field, and my hobbies include: VEX and FRC robotics, competitive programming, chess, and sports.
I would like to learn more about: AI, deep learning, cyber-security, and computer vision.
Please feel free to send me a message for any collaboration or inquiry!
Eric Xie

experiences.title: Robotics Instructor
experiences.description:
As the summer robotics instructor at Under the GUI Academy, I introduced students aged 9-17 to VEX IQ and V5 Robotics. 
For the IQ students, I helped them develop essential STEM skills such as design, coding, as well as soft skills, such as empathy and teamwork. I organized games, like capture the flag or freeze tag so that students have fun while learning something new through hands-on activities.
For the V5 Competitive Robotics, I introduced students to the 2023 Challenge "Over Under". I led the brainstorming process, explained engineering concepts such as gear ratio and wiring, allowed students to fully optimize their creation, and expanded their engineering skill set.
Overall, both groups of students benefited tremendously from UTG\'s robotics summer camp.
experiences.location: North Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada ¬∑ On-site

experiences.title: Police Cadet
experiences.description: From a pool of 60 applicants, I was 1 of 12 high school students chosen to participate in the 2023 West Vancouver Police Youth Academy. During the 5-day camp, we learned how to handcuff, how to match fingerprints, how to handle K-9 police dogs, and how to conduct search and rescue in mountainous regions. Furthermore, we toured an ambulance, took off in a helicopter, completed the POPAT, and exercised with intensive daily workouts. Overall, we experienced, hands-on, the ins and outs of what it's like to be a police officer.
experiences.location: West Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada ¬∑ On-site

accomplishment_courses.name: Physics and Technologies of the Future - Columbia University

accomplishment_projects.title: Vita
accomplishment_projects.description:
üéØ As part of the 2023 UBC STEM Leadership program, our team of 6 high school students was tasked with a sustainable design challenge. The goal was to create a project that promotes sustainability in engineering following one or more of the 17 UN Sustainable Development goals.
üí° The product we proposed was a scalable, zero-electricity, low-cost water-filtration bottle, which we called Vita. With this project, we aimed to help indigenous communities living in rural areas of British Columbia access safe drinking water from lakes and rivers, which due to colonial and historical reasons, remain polluted and under boil-water advisories. With our help, we strive to alleviate the indigenous water crisis, and moreover, we hope to help a wider group of low-income communities access clean drinking water, while reducing plastic waste in single-use water bottles and promoting environmental sustainability.
üõ†Ô∏è Vita consists of several compartments: the outer chamber, the inner chamber connected to a filter, and the cap, and it works similar to a piston. First, you would fill the outer cylinder with unclean water, then you would attach the inner chamber and press down on it. The pressure forces the water to flow through the semi-permeable filter, trapping impurities at the bottom of the outer bottle, while clean water passes and fills the inner bottle. For convenience, we also designed a threaded cap that allows users to remove the inner chamber and retain clean water. The entire process takes around 20 seconds: (demonstration below). Our product could be lifesaving for hikers trapped on mountains, or reserves far from a clean water supply
‚úîÔ∏è Within 3 months, we created a fully functional prototype, a poster board, and our website to document our journey and collective experiences.
üèÜ Our team presented at the STEM LP Gala and has plans to continue working on this project in the future.

accomplishment_projects.title: Nail Braille
accomplishment_projects.description:
üéØ The challenge for SHAD 2022 was to create a product that improves the wellness of Canadians. With this goal in mind, my group and I created a braille learning device focused on helping those who are transitioning from sight to blindness. 
üí° The product we proposed uses speech-to-text to listen for words. Our algorithm will then translate the sound into English, then into braille. Using a series of commands, pins on a board will pop up and down to spell the word in braille. The user then could physically feel the pins, learning what they have said in braille. Our product ensures that learning braille can be done independently, and because the device is small, lightweight, and portable, it can be used in a variety of situations. It would also be much cheaper and more accessible than any other current market competitors, for example, a braille tutor or a braille book.
üõ†Ô∏è Our prototype was created to test the feasibility of using speech-to-text to control the braille pins. Instead of using actual braille pins, we used LED lights which would eventually turn into pins controlled by pistons. By using a computer to run Mozilla's open-source Deepspeech engine and an Arduino controlling LED lights, we were able to demonstrate that our concept was not only attainable, but practical and marketable.
‚úîÔ∏è Within the month, we created a fully functional MVP prototype, business plan, and a successful pitch, which we presented to a panel of judges. 
üèÜ Our team won the SHAD Western Best Prototype award and has plans to continue working on this project via grants in the future.

volunteer_work.title: Tournament Director
volunteer_work.description: I set up the hardware as well as the software to ensure that the tournament runs smoothly. Hardwares include: tables, chairs, judging pits, inspection areas. Softwares include: TM Mobile for the inspectors, score keeper referees, and judges. I am responsible for recruiting and training volunteers, and taking care of the logistics such as food allocation and technical difficulties.

volunteer_work.title: Tournament Manager
volunteer_work.description: I set up the software, Tournament Manager on the main server computer. Then I connect other operating devices to the server, as well as monitors that need to display match scores, inspection status, standings and so on. I am responsible for fixing problems that occur throughout a tournament (which always happen) in a timely and productive manner.
